cc.publication module¶

class cc.publication.Publication(citation_key, notes_categories=['key_concepts', 'key_points', 'uncategorized'], ignore_failed=True)¶

abstract_str(return_empty_upon_failure=True, verbose=False)¶

Retrieve the abstract text, either from the citation or from ADS

Parameters:

return_empty_upon_failure – If True, treat the abstract as an empty string when failing to download the abstract from ADS.

Returns:

String containing the abstract.

Return type:

abstract_str (str)

citations_per_year()¶

Calculate the citations per year. This depends on the instance having access to the ADS entry date and citation list, self.entry_date and self.citations. Note that this is usually automatically done after processing and saving the abstracts.

get_ads_data(fl=['abstract', 'citation', 'reference', 'entry_date'], keep_query_open=False, n_attempts=5, verbose=False, **kwargs)¶

Retrieve all data the NASA Astrophysical Data System has regarding a paper.

NOTE: For this to work you MUST have your ADS API key saved to ~/.ads/dev_key

Parameters:

  • fl (list of strs) – Fields to preload when the data is first retrieved.

  • n_attempts (int) – Number of attempts to access the API. Useful when experiencing connection issues.

Keyword Arguments:

  • number (Unique identifiers of the publication, e.g. the arXiv) –

  • arxiv='1811.11753'. (with) –

Returns:

Dictionary containing ADS data.

Return type:

self.ads_data (dict)

identify_unique_key_concepts(**kwargs)¶

Identify the unique key concepts derived from notes.

Parameters:

**kwargs – Passed to concept.uniquify_concepts.

inner_product_custom(other, method='cached key-point concepts', max_edit_distance=None, **kwargs)¶

Calculate the inner product between the publication and another object.

Parameters:

  • other – The other object to calcualte the inner product with.

  • method (str) –

    How to calculate the inner product. Options are… ‘key-point concepts’:

    The inner product is the the sum of the inner products between all relations in the two publications, and the inner product between two relations is the number of key concepts they share.

    ’cached key-point concepts’:

    Faster but less-accurate version of ‘key-point concepts’.

    ’abstract similarity’:

    The inner product is the sum of the inner product between all sentences in the abstract of each publications. The inner product between two abstract sentences is the number of nouns, verbs, and adjectives (“important” words) shared by the two sentences. (“Important” is up to user choice. I’ve defined it in the config using nltk[‘tag_tier’].)

    max_edit_distance (int):

    If not None this is the Maximum Levenshtein edit-distance between two words for them to count as the same word. Computationally expensive currently.

  • **kwargs – Passed to the inner product between relations.

Raw abstract. If none, download from ADS.

If True, treat the abstract as an empty string when failing to download the abstract from ADS.

process_annotation_line(line, notes=None, word_per_concept=True, conditions=None, forgiving=True)¶

Process a line of annotation to extract more information.

Parameters:

  • line (str) – The line of annotation to process.

  • notes (dict) – The dictionary storing notes on various lines. Defaults to using self.notes.

  • word_per_concept (bool) – If True, break each concept into its composite words.

Returns:

A dictionary containing updates notes on annotations.

Return type:

notes (dict)

  • reload (bool) – Forcibly reprocess annotations, even if already processed.

  • word_per_concept (bool) – If True, break each concept into its composite words.

stemmed_points(verbose=False, tag_mapping=None)¶
vectorize(feature_names=None, include_notes=True)¶

Project the abstract into concept space. In simplest form this can just be counting up the number of times each unique, stemmed noun, verb, or adjective shows up in the abstract.

Parameters:

  • feature_names (array-like of strs) – Basis features to project onto. Defaults to all concepts in the abstract.

  • include_notes (bool) – If True include key_points and uncategorized in the vectorized text.

Returns:

The value of the projection for each concept (by default the

number of times a word shows up in the abstract).

feature_names (np.ndarray of strs):

The component concepts. If the feature_names argument is None then all non-zero concepts in the abstract are used. If not None then the union of the non-zero concepts and the feature_names arg.

Return type:

vector (np.ndarray of ints)
